repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Second Community
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Although the project outcome is
            satisfactory, and institutional development impacts were
            substantial, sustainability is unlikely, given the present
            socio-political conditions, further affected by severe
            budget constraints. Nonetheless, performances are rated
            satisfactory by the Bank, and highly satisfactory by the
            Borrower. Lessons address the following: a) flexibility in
            design: interventions designed in a
            post-conflict/in-conflict area should have flexibility so as
            to absorb shocks, and still be relevant in meeting the
            projects development objective. Furthermore, the ability to
            respond to rapid changes on the ground - such as removing
            the requirement for community cash contributions when the
            poverty rates had risen - ensured that the poorest, who the
            project was designed to serve, were not the ones left out
            due to stringent requirements; 2) development objective: the
            importance of having a clearly focused development objective
            allowed addressing monitoring and measurement of
            achievements, which would have been difficult if both
            short-term emergency priorities, and long-term development
            activities been encompassed; 3)targeting strategy: the
            development and use of the poverty map for identifying
            project areas, assisted the implementing agencies (IAs) to
            target the resources for maximum impact. Moreover, the
            poverty map and targeting strategy provided the IAs with a
            clear, and transparent project rationale. Further lessons
            address the successful partnerships established in
            attracting co-financing, while having a local, and
            decentralized presence highly contributed to achieve empowerment.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Second Community
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the context of the Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS), the Second Community Development
            Project supports the replenishment of the Trust Fund for the
            West Bank and Gaza, and highlights the need for a sustained
            growth, through an equitable process, as specified in April
            1998. The project is a follow-up to the first phase project,
            and will continue to improve infrastructure services.
            Nevertheless, the strategy will be redefined to target
            marginal and poor communities, thus, poverty alleviation and
            human resource development becomes the overall sector
            objective, with emphasis on poor areas identification,
            focusing on labor-intensive micro-projects, which will not
            only preserve capital assets, but increase and promote local
            job opportunities. Significant portions of project
            activities are expected to take place in refugee camps, to
            be implemented with no prejudice against the refugees's
            inalienable rights. The components of the project include:
            1) Local government units will identify and implement
            infrastructure micro-projects. Mostly local contractors,
            suppliers and laborers will perform work improvements in
            infrastructure. 2) Technical assistance will be provided to
            local governments to ensure high quality and responsiveness
            in micro-project implementation. Technical assistance will
            also be provided for project management, and to local
            contractors. 3) Supplemental operating costs will be
            provided for project execution and management.
